definitions: To understand or fully grasp something.
To provide shelter or accommodation for someone.
To receive money, especially as income or payment.
To absorb something, such as information or a substance.
examples: She asked the tailor to take in the dress.
It took him a while to take in the news.
Don't be taken in by his charm.
They decided to take in a lodger.
The business didn't take in much profit this quarter.
The plant takes in sunlight through its leaves.
